title: Hanja
summary: Hanja (Korean: 한자; Hanja: 漢字, Korean pronunciation: [ha(ː)nt͈ɕa], or Hancha[1]) is the Korean name for a traditional writing system consisting mainly of Chinese characters (Chinese: 漢字; pinyin: hànzì)[2] that was incorporated and used since the Gojoseon period (400 BC). More specifically, it refers to the Chinese characters incorporated into the Korean language with Korean pronunciation.
